H0.text: Measured with a metric ruler, the hardness, odor, and taste of an object can all be.

H1.text: Measured with a spring scale is how the hardness, odor, and taste of an object can all be assessed.

H2.text: Observed with the senses is how the hardness, odor, and taste of an object can be.

H3.text: Observed with a hand lens, the hardness, odor, and taste of an object can all be.

A4.text: Taste (formally known as gustation) is the ability to perceive the flavor of substances, including, but not limited to, food. Humans receive tastes through sensory organs concentrated on the upper surface of the tongue, called taste buds or gustatory calyculi.

A5.text: Smell is the process of absorbing molecules through olfactory organs, which are absorbed by humans through the nose. These molecules diffuse through a thick layer of mucus; come into contact with one of thousands of cilia that are projected from sensoryæ£¹ neurons; and are then absorbed into a receptor (one of 347 or so).
